SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Does anyone else wonder how this organisation has got away with it for so long without being accountable to anyone?
It's baffled me. Its been so so obvious for so long.

Most other crimes in the footy world have been cracked down on pretty well - racism, match-fixing / organised gambling, violence etc. But the corruption right at the top has just been immune (up until now).

The only explanation I can think of is that the web of corruption is so deep, with so many people on board, that it will take a massive concerted organised effort to take the thing down in one swoop and that is what we are seeing the start of now.

When law enforcement agencies go after mafia bosses, they don't try and nail them on a petty theft charge or assault here and there, they build a portfolio, they take their time, getting moles in place, building up evidence, laying traps, prepping witnesses. That's the only explanation I can think of as to why it has took so long for the police to start getting involved properly

Hope it's taken the shine off the little jolly they are all on at the moment. Just hope the ones they have arrested are supporters of Sepp Blatter in the forthcoming elections, so he will have a few less votes. Or even better, that he too is arrested. And charged.

I'm hoping that the coppers get the people they've arrested under a bright light, offer them leniency if they inform on the higher-ups, then the rug can be pulled out from under SB properly. Can't wait to see the back of him, to see FIFA transform, and to see footy come into the 21st Century
Yes, but then five minutes contemplation provides the answer why:

FIFA's supreme body is the FIFA Congress, an assembly made up of representatives from each of the 209 affiliated member associations. The Congress decides FIFA's governing statutes and their method of implementation and application. Only the Congress can pass changes to FIFA's statutes. The Congress approves the annual report, and decides on the acceptance of new national associations and holds elections. Congress elects the President of FIFA, its General Secretary, and the other members of FIFA's Executive Committee. Each national football association has one vote, regardless of its size or footballing strength.
This is a setup guaranteed to put the power in the hands of delegates on the make. Uncorrupt delegates from Western Europe will always be outvoted by those on the take.

It is a system that has made Septic Bladder bomb-proof. If he's not pilfering from the till himself, he looks the other way when those who back him do. Septic's deal with his dodgy delegates is ''we want to develop the beautiful game in poor nations, accordingly we propose you vote to allocate big pots of FIFA cash for that purpose". This is an offer they can't refuse. Delegates from poor nations are in the majority. The money goes to delegates countries via their sticky hands. And they in return turn vote for Septic who again proposes that even more of the dosh they have made off the back of their monopoly control of the world's most profitable jamboree, goes to the developing nations. And so the cycle of corruption perpetuates itself.

The way FIFA is set up it looks impossible to stop corruption. The system is money for votes. Voting delegates get double payola, once from FIFA to develop their associations football (translation $5m for me and $5m for my country's football development and all I have to do is vote for nice Mr Bladder), then they get more dosh in the bribes they take from officials representing countries bidding to stage the WC.
The only way to stop this corruption is for the football powerhouses in Europe plus Argentina, Brazil, USA, Australia and Japan to leave FIFA and set up their own competition. But they won't.

Agreed to all of that apart from the last bit - FIFA officials have been squarely above the law until now, as far as I'm aware this level of police involvement has been unprecedented and I see no reason why it can't lead to real change

The FBI are involved, they've got concrete evidence of $100m+ of bribes, 47 charges already made going back 24 years, evidence of corruption in presidential campaigns... and much more to come I'm guessing.
This isn't a trifling match-fixing scandal in the Croatian 3rd division, big heads are going to roll.

How, when the corrupt have all the votes? If you dump one corrupt official from tin-pot member country The Democratic People's Republic of Bongoland, there will be a couple of dozen others from that country queuing to take his seat and vote at the Congress.
And there are several types of corruption happening.
How are you planning to change the way FIFA is run?

But the Congress votes for the Executive on a system of 'one member one vote' and they will always vote for an executive that gives them what they want. You can't change the rules unless the members vote for it and they are not going to do that. The countries that provide all the money don't have all the votes.
up until now there has been basically a 0% chance that giving/ receiving a bribe would lead to any kind of punishment.

By the time this whole thing is over, I suspect there will be 40+ officials successfully convicted (hopefully/probably including Blatter himself), and there will be complete police control + transparency of financial goings-on with official FIFA money. The system will not just go on the same after something like that.
Hard to take a bribe with the IRS, FBI and Swiss police standing over your shoulder, or trawling through your accounts. Stop the bribes, stop the system.
But their associations will replace them with new but equally corrupt delegates.

If you get $10m from FIFA to develop football in your country, you and the association who elected you as their representative on the Congress all skim a fat slice off the top. How do you stop that? It's the same as happens to foreign aid money once it's inside the recipient country...
And if you are an official from a bidding country touting for votes to host the next WC the payola you handover doesn't go through anyone's books, not FIFA's that's for sure.

When FIFA is stripped nakedly transparent for all the world to see, this would surely deter potential replacements queuing up to replace those being prosecuted (if they are). If the organisation implodes, then another, minus such obvious corruption, would surely have to replace it. There are enough football people willing this to happen. If not, it would have to be an organisation which could govern the game with complete impartiality. Profit making yes, but transparent in its financial dealings. This must be the beginning of the end for Blatter and his cronies.

It was the US, who are NOT major soccer fans, who took action. Until this point all soccer organisations kept their mouth shut. Now, of course, they are all defending the US action. Surprise, surprise... But no doubt the US sporting community will benefit from the change of commercial sponsorship...
Blatter retains his post because if he goes stories will be told.
I think the politics surrounding Russia and Qatar have more to do with the US investigations of FIFA than any interest it has in the sport or administration itself...

Still, it's nice to think that there are lots of squeaky bums in that posh Swiss hotel tonight. Enough to get their snouts out of the truffles for a while. Lots of secret meetings going on re back covering.

The silence and cowardice of the European, South American, African and Asian football clubs is astounding. No doubt there are quite a few corrupt members in those administrations...All will be revealed, eh?
Wherever money is to made, there is corruption. Banks, Multi-nationals and Sports administrations...They are all experts in corruption.

corruption or not regards Blatter, it's unhealthy for any organisation to have the same man in charge for such a length of time. If he had any dignity, even IF he was innocent of wrongdoing (stop laughing at the back) then he would accept this happened on his watch and step down. Bottom line is he's pushing 80 and even if convicted of anything would be unlikely to see jail or one that didn't resemble a 4 star hotel.
Unhealthy' for the same man to be in charge? Jesus wept...
There are several ways those on the make get their payola:

a) Taking a slice off sponsorship contracts (Coca-Cola, Visa, Adidas, TV companies and others) obtained by your regional confederation, e.g. by CONCACAF - Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football. Chuck Blazer is alleged to have taken commissions of 10% ("override fees") - on all sponsorship and TV rights deals he negotiated through his company Sportvertising. Blazer will argue that he had an above-board deal with CONCACAF which entitled him to "override fees".

b) Bribes from countries bidding for the WC paid to FIFA officials on the 24 man Selection Committee, under the counter. There will always be Delegates who are willing to take a backhander which if necessary will be shared with other officials from their association back home. How are the FBI or the Swiss police going to stop payments from bidding country X being paid into an account in a tax haven that refuses to disclose details of customers accounts, that is then accessed by corrupt members of the national association? Or made in US dollars and delivered to the bribed Selection Committee members in their own Godforsaken country where the rule of law means, you get justice by paying off the judges? The sums of money the officials are making are large, particularly for people from the Third World, and there will be no shortage of takers willing to risk getting caught

c) FIFA bosses like Blatter get delegates votes to maintain the present cosy corrupt setup, and themselves in office, by proposing the organisation pays ever increasing amounts of its profits to Third World member associations, whose officials skim off a thick slice for themselves. The payments are approved by a majority of the 209 member associations, no bribery there, however the dosh doesn't go where it's intended, the grassroots, but to the people running the recipient countries associations. It's like the overseas aid scams. How under the present set up do you stop that?
Payola won't be stopped as long as there are 209 member associations each with equal voting rights.

I agree the only way to stop corruption is to create a new organisation that is controlled by the powerhouses of world football, because if you let the small nations have an equal say they will always get the FIFA they want by out voting Europe, USA, Japan, and Australia. Out of the window with the world family of football.
Bladder and his staff have a symbiotic relationship with the delegates from 'Developing Countries' and their associations.
Septic's stated mission is to foster development of the beautiful game in lands where lads play barefoot on rubbish tips with balls made from rags.
